ChatGPT says:
*Add App1 to DS1.
First, you need to add the application to the deployment share.
*Modify CustomSettings.ini.
After adding the application, you need to ensure that it is included in the task sequences by modifying the CustomSettings.ini file.
*Modify a selection profile.
Finally, you modify a selection profile to include the application in the deployment.

discussion.content:
Correct B. a deployment profile.

In the Microsoft Intune admin center, a deployment profile allows you to configure various settings for the Autopilot deployment, including the Out-of-box experience (OOBE) settings. Within the deployment profile, you can define options such as language and region settings, privacy settings, Wi-Fi configuration, and more to customize the initial setup experience for the provisioned devices.

ESP does nothing by itself. You need to create a deployment profile.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.

You plan to use Windows Autopilot to provision 25 Windows 11 devices.

You need to configure the Out-of-box experience (OOBE) settings.

What should you create in the Microsoft Intune admin center?

You have an Azure AD tenant that contains the devices shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You purchase Windows 11 Enterprise E5 licenses.

Which devices can use Subscription Activation to upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Should be A
Devices must be Microsoft Entra joined or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined. Workgroup-joined or Microsoft Entra registered devices aren't supported.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-subscription-activation#:~:text=for%20identity%20management.-,Devices%20must%20be%20Microsoft%20Entra%20joined%20or%20Microsoft%20Entra%20hybrid%20joined.%20Workgroup%2Djoined%20or%20Microsoft%20Entra%20registered%20devices%20aren%27t%20supported.,-For%20Microsoft%20customers

The Suibscription does NOT upgrade Windows 10 pro to windows 11 Enterprise

A


Subscription Activation allows devices to upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise if they have the appropriate license assigned to them in the Azure AD tenant. Since Windows 11 Enterprise E5 licenses have been purchased, only Azure AD Joined devices are eligible for Subscription Activation. Therefore, only Device1 can use Subscription Activation to upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise.

Selected Answer: A
AD Registered device cannot be activated.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-subscription-activation?pivots=windows-11#windows-enterprise-requirements

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. Answer A is Device 1 only and Device 1 is the same as Device 3; therefore, both Device 1 and 3 are correct.

Selected Answer: A
Devices must be Microsoft Entra joined or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined. Workgroup-joined or Microsoft Entra registered devices aren't supported.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-subscription-activation?pivots=windows-10#subscription-activation-for-enterprise:~:text=for%20identity%20management.-,Devices%20must%20be%20Microsoft%20Entra%20joined%20or%20Microsoft%20Entra%20hybrid%20joined.%20Workgroup%2Djoined%20or%20Microsoft%20Entra%20registered%20devices%20aren%27t%20supported.,-For%20Microsoft%20customers

Selected Answer: C
"Devices with a current Windows Pro edition license can be seamlessly upgraded to Windows Enterprise."

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-subscription-activation?pivots=windows-10#subscription-activation-for-enterprise

comments.content:
Codeword is "current" 
From 11 to 11 is current. Windows 10 is NOT current.
No. You can only use subscription activation for Entra Joined devices running the same OS version

discussion.content: correct answer is D Device1, Device2, Device3, and Device4

Question 68 ask about which device can be activated with subscription activation: in that case was Dev1 Win11 PRO and Dev3 Win10 PRO.

However, for this question is which device can be upgrade to Win11 Enterprise using Subscription activation, in that case, Only Win11 Pro can be upgraded.

Subscription activation doesn't support Upgrade WIN10 PRO to Win11 Enterprice.

Selected Answer: A
Agree with Darkfire. 
Device must be Entra ID joined.

Correct

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-10-subscription-activation#the-evolution-of-deployment

Selected Answer: A
Devices must be Microsoft Entra joined or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined. 
Workgroup-joined or Microsoft Entra registered devices aren't supported.
Subscription activation doesn't update a device from Windows 10 to Windows 11
It is not the fact that it does not upgrade is the fact that it will take the version to enterprise and allow an upgrade, the question does not say immediately upgrade.

There are several questions like this one and took me time to properly investigate "Subscription Activation is a method for upgrading Windows 10 Pro to Windows 11 Enterprise using the Azure AD join type." Giving answer is correct.

Selected Answer: A
THE CORRECT ANSWER IS A:
Subscription activiation does not UPGRADE windows.

Device 1 only. Subscription activation doesn't upgrade versions.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-10-subscription-activation#the-evolution-of-deployment

Selected Answer: A
The subscription upgrade conditions are: the same Windows OS type and the devices must be Azure AD joined.

Selected Answer: A
100% A

Selected Answer: A
Yes Should be A
Subscription upgrade is about PRO-->ENT. W11 ENT can be made from 11 PRO, so Device1 and Device2. Device 1 is AAD joined-->OK (requires Hybrid joined). Device2 is AAD Registered --> NO. So Answer A.

Selected Answer: A
Should be A !

Selected Answer: A
The subscription activation feature enables you to "step-up" from Windows Pro edition to Enterprise or Education editions, it cannot upgrade from Windows 10 to 11

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 Subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.

You add apps to Intune as shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You need to create an app configuration policy named Policy1 for the Android Enterprise platform.

Which apps can you manage by using Policy1?

comments.content:
I agree

D is correct

Managed Google Play
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-use-android#:~:text=App%20configuration%20policies%20in%20Microsoft%20Intune%20supply%20settings%20to%20Managed%20Google%20Play%20apps%20on%20managed%20Android%20Enterprise%20devices

Line Of Business
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-overview#:~:text=To%20support%20app%20configuration%20through,for%20app%20protection%20policies.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
LOB Apps CAN be configured if meets the following conditions:
"To support app configuration through the MAM channel, the app must be integrated with Intune App SDK. Line-of-business apps can either integrate the Intune App SDK or use the Intune App Wrapping Tool. "

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-overview

I tested this in my own environment. I was able to upload a private .apk to the managed google play store then create both an MAM and MDM app config policy and select the LOB app I had uploaded.
I was also able to create a MAM config policy for the same LOB app but not by uploading it to the managed google play store as a private app, but by uploading it to intune only as a custom app after using the app wrapping tool

regular android store apps could NOT be added to app config profiles

Selected Answer: E
All three apps can be managed with the app config policy, providing that the Android Store App supports Intune management. LOB App can be managed if it's wrapped with Intune App Wrapping Tool, so all of them can be managed

Selected Answer: B
These apps are specifically built and deployed for Android Enterprise and fully support app configuration policies.

Selected Answer: B
In theory answer B is correct, but only because is not explained that the LOB apps is wrapped with intune SDK. So without making assumptions the B is correct, but in real word the D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
D; app1 and app3 , you can apply a policy to both lob and managed g play store

D. Standard Android Store Apps are not typically managed by Android Enterprise policies unless they are added as Managed Google Play apps. Therefore, only the Managed Google Play App (and potentially an Android LOB app deployed via Managed Google Play) can be managed by Policy1.

Not sure what will Microsoft accept as correct answer.
B: Managed Google Play app supports App config policy
D: Android LOB app supports App config policy when wrapped using Intune App Wrapping tool.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
*App1: Android store app - These are general apps available in the Google Play Store.
*App2: Android line-of-business app - These are internally developed apps not listed in the public Google Play Store.
*App3: Managed Google Play app - These are apps managed and distributed through Managed Google Play, which is part of Android Enterprise.

Selected Answer: B
When deploying app config policy to a managed device, which uses the MDM channel, the app must be pinned to the management profile on iOS/iPadOS or deployed through Managed Google Play on Android devices. 
Correct answer is B.
B is right for managing lob you have to use wrapping or sdk

Selected Answer: D
D. App2 and App3 only

B.
For the Android Enterprise platform, app configuration policies can only be applied to Android line-of-business apps or Managed Google Play apps. Therefore, you can only manage App3 using the app configuration policy named Policy1.

Selected Answer: B
I tested, for a policy for the platform supports only Managed Google Play
"managed" is the key word here.
Correct

Selected Answer: B
Seems correct

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-overview
You will only see apps from Managed Google Play store, not the Google Play store, when using Managed Devices as the Enrollment Type for Android devices.
Correct answer.

Selected Answer: B
Correct : https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-use-android
